Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 2: Data Integration for Urban Metabolism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Urban metabolism (UM) is a term that captures the essential functions of cities and their inhabitants: flows and transformations of materials and energy, the movement of people, commerce, the creation of capital, the maintenance and renewal of facilities, and the generation and use of services. In order to study UM, large amounts of heterogeneous data need to be accessed, integrated, and analyzed. This project will investigate the feasibility of a framework for UM that encompasses: (1) The application of appropriate metrics to UM trends to establish whether regime shifts are indicative of greater or lesser sustainable urban states; (2) The identification and integration of disaggregated data for the inputs and outputs of urban systems through their life cycle stages and at various geographic scales.

The interdisciplinary team consists of six investigators (a computer scientist, a civil engineer, an urban planner, an environmental engineer, a medical doctor, and a public health scientist) and of four international collaborators (three computer scientists and one environmental engineer). Broader impacts include providing unique opportunities to educate students in the analysis and design of sustainable urban regions in a variety of socio-cultural contexts. Further, by revealing the connections between physical flows and environmental, social, health, and economic impacts, this research aims to demonstrate the critical need of an integrated systems approach to urban planning, instead of focusing on the end-of-pipe and post-crisis management, as the current paradigm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urban metabolism (UM) is a term that captures the essential functions of cities and their inhabitants: flows and transformations of materials and energy, the movement of people, commerce, the creation of capital, the maintenance and renewal of facilities, and the generation and use of services. When defined properly, UM can be used as an indicator of the dynamic regime that a city or urban region inhabits and can be used to detect regime shifts over time. Detecting such shifts is the first step in assessing the resilience and sustainability of an urban system. Defining and measuring UM indicators is significantly challenging.

 

To study UM, large amounts of heterogeneous data need to be accessed, collected, processed, integrated, visualized and queried. Toward this end, we developed the GIVA platform, a complex system for Geospatial and temporal data Integration, Visualization, and Analytics. From a data science viewpoint, the project seeks to identify, evaluate, simulate, and visualize disaggregated data for the inputs and outputs of urban systems through their life cycle stages and at various geographic scales. In parallel, many multidisciplinary metrics and multi-longitudinal datasets that present high potential and critical challenges for data integration in urban metabolism analysis were investigated. Various local factors were explored that influence resource and waste management at counties and municipalities as case studies of data integration (e.g., food waste, electric vehicle batteries, and renewable energy).

 

A metabolic framework for small-scale urban systems was developed and implemented, where data constraints are particularly challenging. Similarly, metabolic studies in the cases of University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) and peer institutions were developed. Fisher Information (FI) and Data Envelopment Analysis were adapted and used as complementary methods for urban metabolism analysis. FI monitors system stability by defining and counting how many states a system goes through over time as a means to capture the dynamic regimes of a system. The stability of every U.S. public transportation system was evaluated using FI. Using concepts of entropy, the resilience of the energy grid of each U.S. state was evaluated, so as to identify states that were particularly vulnerable to any disruption in the fuel used to generate electricity. Using concepts of network science, a novel Network-based Frequency Analysis (NFA) method was developed and applied to study water consumption patterns in the U.S. A similar approach was used to study and forecast the sustainability of world countries, which enabled us to cluster countries into four groups.

 

The research project was fundamentally interdisciplinary with six researchers from five disciplines: Computer Science, Urban Planning, Environmental Engineering, Civil Engineering, and Public Health. Over the course of the project, 11 graduate and 4 undergraduate students were mentored by one or more of the investigators. The project directly contributed to 5 theses, 30 journal or juried conference papers, 1 book, 1 book chapter, 53 conference presentations, and 3 software packages available in open access format.

 

The large number of scientific publications is an indicator of the technical merit of the project. Qualitatively, the intermingling of ideas induced technical innovation in each discipline in ways that would not have been possible otherwise.

From a broader impact perspective, the historical study of UM may give us an indication of how cities will evolve and, ideally, how that evolution can be guided to curtail the disadvantages of urban living so as to make possible the increasing congregation of people in (mega)cities. UM will be especially important in view of a United Nations study that projects that 68% of the population will live in cities by 2050, while in 2018 that percentage was 55%.
